questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following is a false statement regarding the inguinal canal?

options.a: Conjoint tendon forms a part of the posterior wall
options.b: Superficial ring is an opening in the external oblique aponeurosis
options.c: Deep ring is an opening in the transverse abdominis
options.d: Internal oblique forms both the anterior and superior walls

questions.explanation: The deep inguinal ring is an opening in the fascia transversalis, not in the transversus abdominis.

questions.question:
Question 2: All of the following are contents of inguinal canal except  
.
questions.explanation: The femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve is not a content of the inguinal canal. The contents of the inguinal canal include: • Spermatic cord in males • Round ligament in females • Ilioinguinal nerve in both the sexes. The contents of the spermatic cord include: • Cremaster muscle fibers • Testicular artery and accompanying veins • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve • Vas deferens • Cremasteric vessels • Lymphatics • Processus vaginalis

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following structures does not form the boundary of Hesselbach’s triangle?
questions.explanation:
Vas deferens does not form the boundary of Hesselbach’s triangle. Hesselbach's triangle (also called the inguinal triangle) is a region of the deep part of the anterior 
abdominal wall.

questions.question:
Question 4: A resident while assisting a case of laparoscopic hernia repair observes the surgeon dissect 
certain anatomical landmarks to expose the triangle of doom. Which of the following does not 
form a boundary of this triangle?
questions.explanation:
Cooper’s ligament does not form the boundary of the triangle of doom. 649 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is true regarding inguinal hernia?
questions.explanation:
The medial border of the triangle of doom is bounded by vas deferens and the medial border of 
the myopectineal orifice is bounded by the lateral border of rectus abdominis. The triangle of doom is bounded: • Medially by the vas deferens • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels) • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection The myopectineal orifice is an osseo-myo-aponeurotic tunnel. It is through this tunnel that all 
groin hernias occur. It is bounded: • Medially by the lateral border of the rectus sheath. • Above by the arched fibers of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscle. • Laterally by the iliopsoas muscle. • Below by the pectin pubis and fascia covering it.

questions.question: Question 6: What is the most common type of hernia in females?
questions.explanation:
Indirect inguinal hernias are by far the most common type of hernia in women. It is the most 
common hernia regardless of gender. In men, indirect hernias predominate over direct hernias at a ratio of 2:1. Femoral hernia and 
umbilical hernias are more common in females compared to males at ratios of 10:1 and 2:1, 
respectively. Although femoral hernias occur more frequently in women than in men, inguinal 
hernia remains the most common hernia in women. 650 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: A 45-year-old woman presents with a history of swelling in the right groin for the past 6 
months. On examination, an irreducible hernia is present in the right groin. Which of the 
following structures would be helpful in identifying if the hernia is inguinal or femoral in 
origin?
questions.explanation:
Pubic tubercle is used to differentiate between inguinal and femoral hernias. Inguinal hernia is above and medial to the pubic tubercle. Femoral hernia is below and lateral to the pubic tubercle. Another structure that is useful in differentiating between inguinal and femoral hernia is inguinal 
ligament. An inguinal hernia leaves the abdominal cavity just above the inguinal ligament and a 
femoral hernia leaves just below the inguinal ligament.

questions.question:
Question 8: An elderly male patient is diagnosed with direct inguinal hernia. Which of the following 
statements is true? 639 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: The sac lies medial to the inferior epigastric artery
options.b: Cough impulse is felt on the index finger
options.c: Can descend till the bottom of scrotum
options.d: The neck is narrow and is prone for strangulation

questions.explanation:
The sac and contents of a direct hernia protrude through Hesselbach’s triangle, i.e., medial to the 
inferior epigastric artery.

questions.question:
Question 9: Bubonocele is a type of  
.
questions.explanation:
Bubonocele is a type of indirect inguinal hernia where the hernia is limited to the inguinal canal. Indirect inguinal hernia is more common on the right side because of the delay in atrophy of the 
processus vaginalis after the normal slower descent of the right testis to the scrotum during fetal 
development.

questions.question: Question 10: What is the most common serious complication expected to occur in patients with hernia?
questions.explanation:
Strangulation is the most common serious complication of a hernia. An incarcerated hernia is a part of the intestine or abdominal tissue that becomes trapped in the 
sac of a hernia.An incarcerated hernia can lead to a bowel obstruction or 
strangulation. Obstruction is characterized by colicky abdominal pain, vomiting, abdominal 
distension and obstipation. Features of obstruction along with vascular compromise is seen in 
strangluation. Strangulation occurs in 1% to 3% of groin hernias. It is more common at the 
extremes of life. Most strangulated hernias are indirect inguinal hernias. However, femoral hernias have the 
highest rate of strangulation (15% to 20%) of all hernias, and it is, therefore, recommended that 
all femoral hernias be repaired at the time of discovery. Tenderness is the first sign of 
strangulation. The first step is the correction of hypovolemia. The treatment of choice is immediate surgery. The 
fundus is opened first during surgery.

questions.question:
Question 11: A patient presents with a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery. What is the most 
likely diagnosis and appropriate management for the same?

options.b: Direct hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair
options.d: Indirect hernia and Lichtenstein mesh repair

questions.explanation:
651 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical scenario of a hernia medial to the inferior epigastric artery is suggestive of a 
direct hernia, for which Lichtenstein mesh repair is the appropriate surgical method for its 
management. The contents of a direct hernia protrude outward, forward, and medial to the inferior epigastric 
artery and the deep inguinal ring. Whereas, the contents of an indirect hernia protrude lateral to 
the inferior epigastric artery. The sac of an indirect inguinal hernia passes from the deep inguinal 
ring obliquely towards the superficial inguinal ring and then to the scrotum. A direct hernia protrudes through the Hesselbach triangle, which is a zone of weakness for direct 
hernias. A Lichtenstein mesh repair is currently one of the most frequently used methods for treating an 
inguinal hernia. It is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. It is an anterior 
tension-free mesh repair that reduces the chances of recurrence of a hernia. A piece of prosthetic 
nonabsorbable mesh is used to bridge the defect in this repair. Other surgical methods used for the repair of an inguinal hernia are: • Bassini repair - It is done for the reconstruction of the inguinal floor in adults. In this method, a 
mesh is not used. It is associated with a high recurrence and is not used frequently now. It is used 
only in cases of hernial strangulation and peritonitis where the use of a mesh is not preferred. It is 
performed by suturing the transversus abdominis and internal oblique musculoaponeurotic 
arches/conjoined tendon to the inguinal ligament. • Shouldice repair - It is a multilayered repair, where the posterior wall of the inguinal canal is 
strengthened by continuous sutures. It involves double-breasting of the transversalis fascia. It is 
associated with a very low recurrence rate. • Gilbert repair (plug and patch repair) - It is an extension of Lichtenstein’s original mesh repair 
and has now become the most commonly performed primary anterior inguinal hernia repair. In 
this technique, a cone-shaped plug of polypropylene mesh is used. It is deployed like an 
upside-down umbrella when inserted into the internal inguinal ring to occlude the hernia • McVay repair (Cooper's ligament repair) is used for the correction of direct inguinal hernia, large 
indirect hernia, recurrent hernia, femoral hernias (particularly suited for strangulated femoral 652 
Sold by @itachibot hernias). In this method, the transversus abdominis aponeurosis is approximated to Cooper's 
ligament. • Stoppa-Rives repair - It is used for the repair of large, recurrent, or bilateral hernias. In this 
method, a sub-umbilical midline incision is given to place a large mesh into the preperitoneal 
space. • Herniotomy - It is used to treat inguinal hernia in a child which occurs due to the presence of 
a patent processus vaginalis. Therefore in herniotomy, the repair of the inguinal ring is not done.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 50-year-old obese male patient presented with bilateral, large inguinal hernias. He had 
been operated on for hernia twice in the past and is now posted for Stoppa's repair. Which of 640 
Sold by @itachibot the following statements regarding this procedure is false?

options.a: This procedure refers to open preperitoneal hernia repair
options.b: The mesh is placed in the retromuscular space
options.c: The mesh needs to be sutured to the posterior rectus sheath in case of small defects
options.d: This procedure is based on the principle of Pascal's law

questions.explanation:
With smaller defects, the mesh does not need to be sutured in Stoppa's repair. This is based on Pascal's law. Pascal’s law states that any additional pressure exerted on an 
enclosed fluid mass is transmitted equally in all directions.The abdomen is an enclosed space and 
intra-abdominal pressure is distributed equally over the mesh, thereby keeping the mesh in place. Stoppa's repair is an open preperitoneal mesh repair primarily indicated for large, recurrent, 
bilateral hernias. In Stoppa’s mesh repair, a large piece of mesh is placed in the retro muscular space, over the 
posterior rectus sheath or peritoneum. This mesh is not sutured in patients with small defects 
because it is held in place by intra-abdominal pressure (Pascal’s law). This allows the eventual 
incorporation of the mesh with the surrounding tissues. Alternatively, in larger defects, the mesh 
can be secured laterally with several sutures.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 2-year-old boy was brought to the clinic with a history of a reducible and painless swelling 
in the right groin for the past 2 months. After the clinical and radiological investigations, the 
diagnosis of a right-sided inguinal hernia was made. The patient is posted for hernia repair 
surgery. Which of the following steps will not be done in this patient during the repair?
questions.explanation:
Inguinal hernia in a child is treated by herniotomy. In this procedure, repair of the inguinal ring is 
not done. 653 
Sold by @itachibot This is because the inguinal hernia in the pediatric population is due to the presence of patent 
processus vaginalis and not due to the weakening of the abdominal muscles or the ligaments. Herniotomy involves either reduction of the hernial sac alone, or opening of the hernial sac, 
reduction of the contents, transfixation of the neck, and excision of the patent processus vaginalis/ 
hernial sac.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following is the most appropriate mesh for use in hernioplasty?
questions.explanation:
The most appropriate mesh used in hernioplasty is a lightweight mesh with large pores. Lightweight meshes generally contain less material and induce a less-pronounced foreign body 
reaction and decreased inflammatory response, which results in better tissue incorporation, 
increased prosthesis compliance, and decreased patient discomfort and pain. Meshes with large pores exhibit less inflammatory infiltrate, connective tissue, and scar bridging, 
which allows increased soft tissue ingrowth. They have greater elasticity and flexibility and also 
shrink less resulting in lesser adhesions, better tissue incorporation, and decreased patient 
discomfort and pain. So the best mesh type among the given options is lightweight mesh with 
large pores. Meshes used in hernioplasty can be synthetic or biological depending on their composition. Synthetic meshes are made from polypropylene, polyester, or PTFE (polytetrafluoroethylene). PTFE meshes are hydrophobic with a lower risk of adhesion. Biological meshes are acellular matrix materials derived from humans or animals and have lesser 
complications. But due to poor collagen deposition and absorption, they rapidly lose mechanical 
strength and hence their use is restricted to infected environments. Note: To promote better tissue integration, a composite mesh was developed which combines the 
attributes of polypropylene and PTFE by layering the two substances on top of one another. POLYESTE

questions.question:
Question 15: A patient operated for direct inguinal hernia developed sensory loss at the root of the penis 
and adjacent part of the scrotum. Which of the following nerves is most likely injured?
questions.explanation:
Loss of sensation in the root of the penis and adjacent part of the scrotum is suggestive of an 
injury to the ilioinguinal nerve. It is most commonly injured within the inguinal canal in open 
hernia repair due to traction or thermal injury. 654 
Sold by @itachibot The iliohypogastric nerve carries the sensory supply from the suprapubic area. Injury to this nerve 
in the right iliac fossa rarely causes sensory disturbances, as the suprapubic area has a rich nerve 
supply from other sources too. If the nerve is severed above the anterior superior iliac spine, it can 
lead to the weakened posterior wall of the inguinal canal resulting in direct inguinal hernia. 
Iliohypogastric nerve can also get injured following appendicectomy. Injury to the genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve results in loss of sensation in the skin of 
the scrotum of males, and loss of sensation of the mons pubis and labia majora in females. Injury to the femoral branch of the genitofemoral nerve causes hypoesthesia over the anterior 
thigh below the inguinal ligament.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 50-year-old male patient with chronic constipation is diagnosed with Type 7 Gilbert hernia. 
This refers to
questions.explanation: Femoral hernia is classified under type 7 Gilbert hernia. As per Nyhus classification system, femoral hernia is classified under type 3C.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following statements about femoral hernia is true?

options.b: All femoral hernias should be repaired
options.d: Femoral vein lies medial to the sac

questions.explanation:
All femoral hernias should be repaired and incarcerated femoral hernias should have the hernia 
sac contents examined for viability. Option A: Femoral hernia occurs in both males and females, but it is more common in 
multiparous females. Femoral hernia is more common on the right side because of 
the tamponading effect of the sigmoid colon on the left femoral canal. This effect is absent on the 
right side. Option C: The incidence of strangulation in femoral hernias is high because of the narrowness of 
the neck of the sac and rigidity of the femoral ring. Option D: Femoral vein is situated lateral to a femoral hernia (femoral canal). 655 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 19: In Laugier’s hernia, the opening is in the
questions.explanation:
Laugier’s hernia is an atypical femoral hernia where the sac herniates through a gap in the lacunar 
(Gimbernat’s) ligament. 656

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following statements about Spigelian hernia is false?

options.a: It occurs above the level of the arcuate line
options.b: The hernia sac is posterior to the external oblique aponeurosis
options.c: Most commonly presents as a painless mass

questions.explanation:
Usually, Spigelian hernias do not present as a mass because it is beneath the intact external 
oblique aponeurosis. The most common presentation in Spigelian hernia is pain. There is a common misconception that they protrude below the arcuate line owing to the 
deficiency of the posterior rectus sheath at that level; but in fact, the defect is almost always above 
the arcuate line.

questions.question:
Question 21: While performing an elective hernia repair, the surgeon notices that the posterior wall of the 
hernia sac is formed by the sigmoid colon. What is this type of hernia known as?
questions.explanation:
657 
Sold by @itachibot The given clinical scenario is that of a sliding hernia. Sliding hernia occurs when an internal organ composes a portion of the wall of the hernia sac. The most common viscus involved are as follows: • Left side: sigmoid colon and its mesentery • Right side: cecum It is more common on the left side. Most sliding hernias are variants of indirect inguinal hernias. 
The primary danger associated with a sliding hernia is the failure to recognize the visceral 
component of the hernia sac resulting in injury to the bowel or bladder. Option A: A lumbar hernia is a posterolateral body wall hernia where the bowel, omentum, or 
pre-peritoneal fat herniates through the lumbar triangles. Option C: A Spigelian hernia occurs through slit-like defects in the anterior abdominal wall 
adjacent to the semilunar line. Most spigelian hernias occur in the lower abdomen where the 
posterior sheath is deficient. It is also called “spontaneous lateral ventral hernia” or “hernia of the 
semilunar line”. Option D: A pantaloon hernia occurs when both a direct and an indirect hernia develop on the 
same side of the groin. The hernia is named pantaloon because the two hernia sacs are divided by 
epigastric vessels, and so they look like a pair of pants.

questions.question:
Question 22: A middle-aged male patient underwent adrenalectomy for Cushing's syndrome one year back. 
He now presents with a history of chronic lower back pain. On examination, a partially 
reducible mass that increased in size during Valsalva maneuver was noticed on his lower 
back. Which of the following statements regarding the patient's condition is false?

options.a: Herniation may have occured through the Grynfelt’s triangle
options.b: The inferior lumbar triangle is bound by the external oblique and latismus dorsi muscle
options.c: Herniation is relatively more common on the right side
options.d: Dowd Ponka technique is used for surgical repair

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an iatrogenic lumbar hernia which developed due to 
weakening of the posterior abdominal wall due to surgery. It occurs more commonly on the left 
side. A lumbar hernia is a posterolateral body wall hernia where the bowel, omentum, or pre-peritoneal 
fat herniates through the lumbar triangles. Causes can be congenital, acquired, traumatic, or 
iatrogenic. It is frequently confused for lipomas, muscle strains, fibromas, abscesses, and kidney 
tumors.

questions.question:
Question 23: Which type of hernia is depicted in the following diagram? 643 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The diagram shows Maydl’s hernia/Hernia-en-W/retrograde hernia, where 2 loops of the bowel 
remain in the hernia sac with the connecting loop inside the abdomen. Option A: In Richter's hernia, a small portion of the antimesenteric wall of the intestine is trapped 
within the hernia. Strangulation can occur without the presence of intestinal obstruction. 
Clinically, it mimics gastroenteritis. Option B: In Littre’s hernia, Meckel’s diverticulum is the content. Amyand’s hernia is an inguinal 
hernia in which the hernia sac contains a normal or acutely inflamed appendix. Option C: Petersen hernia is caused by the herniation of intestinal loops through the defect 
between the small bowel limbs, the transverse mesocolon, and the retroperitoneum, after any type 658 
Sold by @itachibot of gastrojejunostomy.

questions.question:
Question 24: A 25-year-old fit athlete presents to the OPD with complaints of nausea and heartburn. On 
examination, a soft, pea-sized swelling could be palpated on his abdomen. What is the likely 
diagnosis in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is epigastric hernia, also known as fatty hernia of linea alba. Epigastric hernia is located between the xiphoid process and umbilicus, usually in the midline. It 
occurs more commonly in males. A soft midline swelling can be felt more easily than seen. Pain 
occurs due to the incarceration of the preperitoneal fat and may simulate peptic ulcer. There is no 
overlying sac.

questions.question:
Question 25: An 83-year-old lady was brought to the OPD with a two-day history of nausea, thigh pain and 
obstipation. Her family reported a significant weight loss over the last year attributed to 
grieving over her son's death. On examination, there is no lump in her groin. But, she 
experiences pain along the anteromedial aspect of her thigh which is relieved by thigh flexion. 
Which of the following statements regarding her condition is true?

options.a: Femoral hernia is the most likely diagnosis
options.b: Howship Romberg sign can be elicited
options.c: Transinguinal approach is preferred for surgery
options.d: These hernias are almost always interparietal

questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario and examination findings are suggestive of obturator hernia. 
Howship-Romberg sign can be seen in patients with obturator hernia. Howship-Romberg sign refers to pain in the anteromedial aspect of the thigh due to compression 
of the obturator nerve that is relieved by thigh flexion. Obturator hernia is also known as skinny old lady hernia and French hernia. It occurs more 
commonly in thin, elderly, debilitated females. Predisposing factors are: • Women with wider pelvis and more triangular obturator canal • Malnutrition • Chronic constipation • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) • Multiparity • Ascites • Kyphoscoliosis Intestinal obstruction can occur. Option A: Femoral hernias commonly present as a small lump in the groin. They may be 
asymptomatic or present with strangulation in about 30% of patients. Option C: A posterior approach, open or laparoscopic surgery is the treatment of choice. This 
approach provides direct access to the hernia. Option D: Interparietal hernias are rare and occur when the sac lies between layers of the 
abdominal wall. These hernias most frequently occur in previous incisions. Spigelian hernias are 
almost always interparietal. 659 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 26: Hernia with hydrocele is known as  
.
questions.explanation:
Gibbon’s hernia is a hernia with hydrocele. Option B: Berger’s hernia is hernia into the pouch of Douglas. Option C: Beclard’s hernia is femoral hernia through the opening of the saphenous vein. Option D: Ogilvie’s hernia is hernia through a defect in conjoint tendon just lateral to where it 
inserts with the rectus sheath. Edward Gibbon, the author of "The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire," was greatly 
embarrassed by a large hydrocele. The second time that it was tapped, it became infected, and 
Gibbon died a few days later. The hydrocele was associated with a large scrotal hernia which had 
probably been punctured.

questions.question:
Question 28: A young female patient who had been suffering from chronic abdominal pain is rushed to the 
casualty due to acute exacerbation. On further investigations, she is diagnosed with intestinal 
obstruction secondary to a paraduodenal hernia. Which of the following statements regarding 
the hernia is false?

options.a: Left-sided hernia is found in the fossa of Landzert
options.b: Right sided hernia is found in the fossa of Kolb
options.d: It is more common on the right side

questions.explanation:
Paraduodenal hernia is more common on the left side (75%). Option A: In Left-sided paraduodenal hernia, bowel herniates through the fossa of Landzert. Option B: In right-sided paraduodenal hernia, bowel herniates through the fossa of 
Waldeyer/Kolb. 661 
Sold by @itachibot Both the fossa of Landzert and the fossa of Waldeyer/Kolb are formed due to congenital 
mesenteric fusion defects. Option C: Paraduodenal hernia is the most common internal hernia and they are usually 
congenital.

questions.question:
Question 29: 645 
Sold by @itachibot An infant who is diagnosed with congenital hypothyroidism presents with the following 
hernia. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of this child?

options.a: The hernia may spontaneously resolve by 2 years of age
options.b: Surgical repair is indicated if the hernia persists for more than 5 years of age
options.c: Strangulation is a common complication associated with this hernia in this child
options.d: Mayo’s procedure or mesh repair can be done for this hernia

questions.explanation:
The given clinical history of congenital hypothyroidism and the image showing a mass protruding 
out of the umbilicus are indicative of an umbilical hernia. Obstruction and strangulation are 
uncommon below the age of 3 years. Mayo’s operation is done for umbilical hernia. A small curved incision is made below the 
umbilicus and the neck of the sac is opened. The contents are returned to the peritoneal cavity 
and the redundant sac is excised after closing it. Defect in the linea alba is closed with interrupted 
sutures. Indications for surgery in umbilical hernia are: • Defect size >2cm • Persisting beyond 5 years • Progressively enlarging after 2 years of age (usually regresses spontaneously by 2 years of age) • Symptomatic • Strangulated In adults, defects up to 2cm in diameter may be sutured primarily with minimal tension. 
However, with larger defects, mesh reinforcement will be beneficial.

questions.question:
Question 30: A baby was born with a congenital defect as shown below. Which of the following statements 
is false regarding this condition? 646 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: It is due to failure of physiological hernia to reduce before 7 weeks
options.d: Topical application of silver nitrate is done

questions.explanation:
662 
Sold by @itachibot The congenital defect showing herniation of the intestinal contents enclosed in a sac from the 
umbilicus is suggestive of omphalocele. It is due to the failure of the physiological hernia to 
reduce into the abdominal cavity before 10 weeks resulting in non-closure of the umbilical ring. Physiological herniation of the midgut through the umbilicus occurs during the 5th week so as to 
accommodate the rapidly growing intestine and persists until the 10th week. Omphalocele is seen in term babies and is usually associated with other congenital anomalies 
(e.g., trisomy 13, trisomy 18, or Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome) and with increased levels of 
-fetoprotein. An omphalocele may contain the stomach, liver, and intestines. These contents are enclosed in a 
sac. The treatment is as follows: • Preservation of the intact sac with a sterile, moistened, saline gauze or transparent bowel bag. • IV fluids should be started, along with gastric tube decompression and IV antibiotics. • Topical application of povidone-iodine ointment, merbromin (mercurochrome), or silver 
nitrate allows the sac to thicken and epithelialize gradually. • Primary surgical closure is preferred for small to medium-sized defects. 663 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 31: A 3-month-old child presented with umbilical discharge. Abdomen examination was normal 
except for the below finding. The next step of management is?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical image is that of a congenital umbilical anomaly such as patent urachus, urachal 
cyst, and vitelline cyst (resulting from the persistence of omphalomesenteric duct). The next best 
step is the USG abdomen to diagnose if the anomaly is cystic, fibrous or fistula and it's 
connections. Omphalomesenteric duct abnormalities: Vitello intestinal duct or omphalomesenteric duct is the 
connection between the yolk sac and the midgut during embryonic life, which eventually gets 
obliterated. The persistence of the vitellointestinal duct leads to various abnormalities depending 
on which part of the duct remains patent. • Persistence of the proximal intestinal end of the duct leads to Meckel’s diverticula. • Persistence of the distal end near the umbilicus leads to the umbilical polyp or sinus. • Persistence of the distal end with mucus retention leads to the cyst, which may be associated 
with the intestine or the umbilicus by a fibrous band. • A fully patent vitellointestinal duct can lead to an enterocutaneous fistula. 664 
Sold by @itachibot Patent urachus occurs due to the failure of urachus to obliterate, resulting in a connection 
between the bladder and the umbilicus. Urachal cyst occurs when the urachus fails to obliterate but there is no connection between the 
bladder and the umbilicus. The given image below shows a urachal cyst (UC) attached to Meckel’s diverticulum (MD) on one 
side and urinary bladder (UB) on the other side with a patent tract- urachus (U).

questions.question: Question 32: Which of the following is the most commonly seen tumor in the retroperitoneal space?

options.a: Independent origin of the right and left hepatic arteries from the cealic axis
options.b: Replaced right hepatic artery arising from the superior mesentric artery

questions.explanation:
Liposarcoma is the most commonly seen tumor in retroperitoneal space. Retroperitoneal tumors can be benign or malignant. Malignant retroperitoneal tumors may be 
mesodermal (75%), neuroectodermal (24%), or embryonic remnant (1%) in origin. Rarely it can 665 
Sold by @itachibot be urologic or metastatic also. The order of frequency of primary retroperitoneal malignancy is as 
follows: • Liposarcoma • Leiomyosarcoma • Rhabdomyosarcoma • Fibrosarcoma • Malignant nerve sheath tumors Liposarcoma is composed of three histologic varieties (listed in order of decreasing frequency): • Well-differentiated and undifferentiated liposarcoma • Pleomorphic liposarcoma • Myxoid/round cell liposarcoma Among the three subtypes, pleomorphic liposarcoma is the most malignant and often 
metastasizes, while the well-differentiated is the least malignant. Myxoid liposarcoma has 
intermediate malignant behavior. Diagnosis is confirmed by contrast-enhanced CT with CT of the chest to look for metastases. Surgery is the main modality of treatment. Wide excision with complete en bloc dissection is 
done. Post-operative radiotherapy and chemotherapy are used as adjuvant methods. Radiotherapy
